Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of efort one eneds to get the news had declined until it has been more diifcult to avoid the news than to consume it

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

In the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSe news is not longera luxury.

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

Do we have a moral duty to stay informed? In a democracy, the answer is yes.

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

In the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

Do we have a moral duty to stay informed? In a democracy, the answer is yes.

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

In the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

Do we have a moral duty to stay informed? In a democracy, the answer is yes.

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

In the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.

Do we have a moral duty to stay informed? In a democracy, the answer is yes.

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

In the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

Do we have a moral duty to stay informed? In a democracy, the answer is yes.

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions.

In the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.
 Everyone who votes is asked to make a decision that involves knowing what one is deciding between. Uninformed decison making can cause people to suffer (prisoners, the disabled, immigrants and taxpayers, for exa

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

In the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.
 Everyone who votes is asked to make a decision that involves knowing what one is deciding between. Uninformed decision making can cause people to suffer (prisoners, the disabled, immigrants and taxpayers, for example). Since causing suffering is morally bad, an

And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.
 Everyone who votes is asked to make a decision that involves knowing what one is deciding between. Uninformed decision making can cause people to suffer (prisoners, the disabled, immigrants and taxpayers, for example). Since causing suffering is morally bad, and informed voting can decrease

Do we have a moral duty to stay informed? In a democracy, the answer is yes.

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

In the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.
 Everyone who votes is asked to make a decision that involves knowing what one is deciding between. Do we have a moral duty to stay informed? In a democracy, the answer is yes.

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

In the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

Do we have a moral duty to stay informed? In a democracy, the answer is yes.

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

In the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.
 Everyone who votes is asked to make a decision that involves knowing what one is deciding between. Uninformed decision making can cause people to suffer (prisoners, the disabled, immigrants and taxpayers, for example). Since causing suffering is morally bad,  informed voting, which can decrease suffering, is morally good.
But the news is not just about voting.
 Being a good citizen requires that know enough of what is going on in the world to nmake a ho.

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

Do we have a moral duty to stay informed? In a democracy, the answer is yes.

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

In the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.
 Everyone who votes is asked to make a decision that involves knowing what one is deciding between. Uninformed decision making can cause people to suffer (prisoners, the disabled, immigrants and taxpayers, for example). Since causing suffering is morally bad,  informed voting, which can decrease suffering, is morally good.
But the news is not just about voting.
 Being a good citizen requires that know enough of what is going on in the world to nmake a host of iunformed decisions in our eprsonal lives.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

Do we have a moral duty to stay informed? In a democracy, the answer is yes.

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

In the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.
 Everyone who votes is asked to make a decision that involves knowing what one is deciding between. In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

In the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.
 Everyone who votes is asked to make a decision that involves knowing what one is deciding between. Uninformed decision making can cause people to suffer (prisoners, the disabled, immigrants and taxpayers, for example). Since causing suffering is morally bad,  informed voting, which can decrease suffering, is morally good.
But the news is not just about voting.
 Being successful requires that know enough of what is going on in the world to make a host of informed decisions. Ignoring tghe news can be a recipe fo

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

In the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.
 Everyone who votes is asked to make a decision that involves knowing what one is deciding between. Uninformed decision making can cause people to suffer (prisoners, the disabled, immigrants and taxpayers, for example). Since causing suffering is morally bad,  informed voting, which can decrease suffering, is morally good.
But the news is not just about voting.
 Being successful requires that know enough of what is going on in the world to make a host of informed decisions. Ignoring tghe news can be a recipe for, not just politcal, but per

Do we have a moral duty to stay informed? In a democracy, the answer is yes.

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

In the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.
 Everyone who votes is asked to make a decision that involves knowing what one is deciding between. But the news is not just about voting.

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

Do we have a moral duty to stay informed? In a democracy, the answer is yes.

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

And n the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.
 Everyone who votes is asked to make a decision that involves knowing what one is deciding between. Uninformed decision making can cause people to suffer (prisoners, the disabled, immigrants and taxpayers, for example). Since causing suffering is morally bad,  informed voting, which can decrease suffering, is morally good.
But the news is not just about voting.
 Being successful requires that we know enough of what is going on in the world to make a host of informed decisions. Ignoring the news can be a recipe for, not just political, but personal failure!

Ignore the news at your peril.

But tgehting te news is not just about voting.
 Being successful requires that we know enough of what is going on in the world to make a host of informed decisions. Ignoring the news can be a recipe for, not just political, but personal failure!

SoIgnore the news at your peril.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

Do we have a moral duty to stay informed? In a democracy, the answer is yes.

In America's earliest days, voting was restricted to middle and upper class property owners because the founders did not trust that the average information-starved citizen could make good decisions. 

And in the past, the news was almost a luxury. But the Industrial Revolution and its aftermath meant that there was technology allowing anyone who wished to stay informed to do so. And as the twentieth century turned into the twenty-first, the amount of effort one needs to get the news has declined until it is now more difficult to avoid the news than to consume it.
TSo te news is not longera luxury.
 Everyone who votes is asked to make a decision that involves knowing what one is deciding between. Uninformed decision-making can cause people to suffer (prisoners, the disabled, immigrants and taxpayers, for example). So Ignore the news at your peril.
